p:
It is known that structural modifications at atomic level impact elastic properties of simple models [ 89, 90]. In this work an influence of inclusions in the form of a stack of nanolayers on elastic properties has been studied by MC simulations for a model nanocomposite system with purely geometrical interactions. The crystalline phase of HSs of diameter
σ
constituted the matrix of that nanocomposite. The nanolayers oriented perpendicularly to
[ 001 ]
-direction were formed by identical HSs of diameter
σ ′
. When
σ ′
= σ
one gets a cubic f.c.c. phase. It has been shown that for
σ ′
/ σ ≠ 1
the system changes its symmetry from cubic to tetragonal one, because of that change the values of Poisson’s ratio (average, as well as in particular directions) typically increase. However, the directions (e.g.,
[ 100 ] [ 001 ]
) in which the increase of
σ ′
/ σ
causes a decrease of the Poisson’s ratio have also been found. The analysis of the Poisson’s ratio surfaces plotted in spherical coordinates revealed that partially auxetic properties are present for all
σ ′
/ σ
values. Further analysis of the Poisson’s ratio in some particular directions showed that introduction of the nanolayer inclusions causes an increase of the negative Poisson’s ratio in the
[ 101 ]
[
1 ¯
01 ]
-directions for the
σ ′
/ σ
values in the range between 1 and
1.03
. A decrease of the Poisson’s ratio in these directions is observed for
σ ′
/ σ > 1.03
. This behavior is qualitatively different from the one observed e.g., in
[ 110 ]
[ 1
1 ¯
0 ]
-directions, which are equivalent to the former ones in the cubic system. Namely the Poisson’s ratio in the
[ 110 ]
[ 1
1 ¯
0 ]
-directions reaches zero value (within the experimental error) for
σ ′
/ σ ∼ 1.02
. The minimal Poisson’s ratio, equal to
ν = − 0.11
, was observed in the tetragonal systems at
σ ′
/ σ = 1.054
. This minimum value was almost two times smaller compared to the cubic system without the nanolayers (
ν = − 0.059
) at the pressure
p *
= 100
. Studies at lower pressures (from
p *
= 50
to
11.67
) showed that this effect weakens along with the decrease of pressure and becomes hard to be noticed near melting. We relate this observation to the fact that at low pressures, distances between the positions of particles are large enough to compensate size changes of the inclusion particles.
